IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8887 S1381-1169(13)00358-0 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.09.033 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 TG/DTA curves of (A) SBA and GP(x)-SBA, and (B) GP(0.73)-SBA and mXD(y)-GP(0.73)-SBA. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of (A) SBA and GP(x)-SBA, and (B) mXD(y)-GP(x)-SBA. Fig. 3 N2 adsorption isotherms of SBA, GP(0.73)-SBA, and mXD(y)-GP(x)-SBA catalysts. Fig. 4 Pore size distributions of the mXD(y)-GP(x)-support catalysts incorporated on (A) SBA, (B) MCM, and (C) SiO2. Fig. 5 IR spectra of (A) SBA, GP, and GP(0.73)-SBA and (B) mXD, mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA, and pXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA. Fig. 6 Schemes for incorporation of GP and mXD to the mesopores of SBA: (A) with forming homogeneous layers and (B) random filling. Fig. 7 Variations of the conversion with reaction time, temperature, and the amount of catalyst added in the Knoevenagel condensation of BA and ECA over mXD. Fig. 8 Variations of conversion with reaction time, temperature, and catalyst amount added in the Knoevenagel condensation of BA and ECA over mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA. Activity improvement of xylylenediamine as a base catalyst by incorporation in SBA-15 mesoporous material HongBo Li Seong Wook Lim Jong-Ho Kim Gon Seo ⁎ School of Applied Chemical Engineering and Research Institute for Catalysis, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 500-757, Republic of Korea School of Applied Chemical Engineering and Research Institute for Catalysis, Chonnam National University Gwangju 500-757 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 62 5301876; fax: +82 62 5301819. Graphical abstract TOF values over mXD and pXD in the Knoevenagel condensation of BA and ECA significantly increased by the incorporation of them in SBA-15. Meta- and para-xylylenediamine (mXD and pXD, totally XD) were incorporated on SBA-15, MCM-41, and amorphous silica supports using 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxy silane (GP) as a connecting material. The amounts and states of GP and XD incorporated in silica supports were examined by thermogravimetry, X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption, SEM, and FT-IR. The catalytic activities of XD catalysts incorporated on the supports were investigated in the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate. The maximum amount of GP incorporated in SBA-15 was 0.73mmol/g, and that of mXD was 0.38mmol/g on GP(0.73)-SBA, indicating that one mXD molecule was combined with two GP molecules. The incorporation of mXD on the silica supports through GP enhanced the catalytic activity of mXD in the condensation from TOF=0.0072s−1 on liquid-state mXD to 0.0258s−1 on mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA. The improvement of the catalytic activities of XD by the incorporation was explained by the increase of the basicity according to the conversion of primary amine to secondary amine. The effects of the size and shape of pores on the catalytic performance of the XD catalysts incorporated in the silica supports in the condensation are discussed. Keywords Xylylenediamine Catalytic activity Knoevenagel condensation Incorporation Silica supports 1 Introduction Homogeneous base catalysts such as potassium hydroxide and sodium hydroxide have been widely used in commercial processes because of their high activity and convenience [1–3]. However, the homogeneous base catalysts inevitably produce huge amounts of basic wastewater during separation of products. The essential limitation of their repeated use and the corrosion of reactors by liquid-phase bases also reduce the competitiveness of the processes catalyzed by homogeneous bases. As a result, incorporated organic base catalysts that can be easily separated by filtration and repeatedly used without further treatment have been prepared by the incorporation of organic bases on stable solid supports through covalent bonds [4–8]. Phosphazenium hydroxide incorporated in silica retains its high basic character, even after incorporation, resulting in high activity in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol [9]. Since the incorporated phosphazenium hydroxide does not dissolve in various organic solvents, the incorporated catalysts can be easily recovered by simple filtration, and can be applied to repeated uses without further treatment. However, the steric restriction toward incorporated base moieties and the mass transfer limitation due to the porous characteristics of supports usually reduce the catalytic activity of bases incorporated in solid supports. A catalyst prepared by the incorporation of 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD) in MCM-41 mesoporous material showed about one third the catalytic activity compared to liquid-state TBD in the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol [10,11]. The catalytic activity of organic bases incorporated in solid supports is generally reduced. The activity of imidazole catalyst incorporated in KIT-1 was reduced to 73% that of liquid-state imidazole [12]. A method for the incorporation of organic bases without reducing their original activities should be developed for the effective application of heterogenized-organic base catalysts to various processes. Xylylenediamine (XD) has two methyleneamine groups substituted on a benzene ring, and shows a medium basicity of pK b =4.3. m-Xylylenediamine (mXD) with meta substitution has been used as a hardening catalyst for epoxy resin, as a raw material for polyurethane, and as a component of adhesive [13], because of its low cost among the isomers of XD. Additionally, mXD can be incorporated easily in silica, because it has two methyleneamine groups that react with many other functional groups. For example, the methyleneamine groups of mXD react with epoxy groups of 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxy silane (GP) incorporated in silica, resulting in the incorporation of mXD in silica through covalent bonds. Furthermore, the conversion of the primary amine groups of mXD to secondary amine groups increases the basicity of the incorporated mXD moieties [14]. Therefore, the incorporation of mXD in silica supports using GP as a connecting material may produce more efficient base catalysts in terms of the strength of basic sites and the convenience accompanying heterogenization. In this study, several mXD and p-xylylenediamine (pXD) base catalysts have been prepared by reacting mXD and pXD with GP-incorporated silica supports with different pore structures. Mesoporous materials of MCM-41 and SBA-15 with uniform linear mesopores but different pore sizes and amorphous silica without definite pore shape and size were used. The physicochemical properties of the XD-incorporated catalysts prepared were examined using thermogravimetry (TG), X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption, and FT-IR spectroscopy. The catalytic performance of the XD-incorporated catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde (BA) and ethyl cyanoacetate (ECA) has been examined to verify the improvement of the catalytic activity of XD with the incorporation, and to confirm the feasibility of repeated use. 2 Experimental 2.1 Supports Three kinds of silica were used as catalyst supports: MCM-41, SBA-15, and amorphous silica. MCM-41 mesoporous material was synthesized using hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (99.5%, Aldrich) as a structure directing agent (SDA) following a previously described procedure [9]. In the preparation of SBA-15 mesoporous material, poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly (ethylene glycol) [average Mn ∼5800, Aldrich] was used as an SDA [15]. The SDA retained in mesopores was removed by calcination at 550°C for 12h. A commercial silica gel (grade 635, 60–100 mesh, 99%, Aldrich) was used as an amorphous silica support. MCM-41, SBA-15, and amorphous silica are abbreviated hereafter as MCM, SBA, and SiO2, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of XD-incorporated catalysts GP (98%, Aldrich) was reacted with silica supports in toluene (99.5%, Daejung) to incorporate GP in the supports. The amount of GP added to the 1-g silica support was varied in the range of 0.3–4.0mmol. After refluxing for 6h, the GP-incorporated silica supports obtained were washed with methylene chloride (99.5%, Daejung) and dried in an oven at 100°C for 12h.mXD (99%, Aldrich) was subsequently incorporated in the GP-incorporated silica supports by refluxing in toluene. The amount of mXD was adjusted to be less than that of the GP incorporated in the silica supports. After refluxing for 6h, the filtered solid was washed using methanol (99.9%, Aldrich) and methylene chloride. The mXD-incorporated silica catalysts were obtained by removing solvent with a rotating evaporator at 45°C for 3h. pXD (99%, TCI) was also incorporated in SBA following the same method used in the incorporation of mXD. The GP-incorporated supports and XD-incorporated catalysts are denoted as GP(x)-supports and XD(y)-GP(x)-support, respectively. x stands for the millimoles of GP incorporated in a gram of silica support, and y stands for the millimoles of mXD or pXD incorporated. The direct reaction of mXD with GP in toluene produced an adduct (mXD-GP). After refluxing for 6h, the solid adduct was filtered and then washed with methanol and methylene chloride. 2.3 Characterization Thermogravimetric analyses of the XD-incorporated silica catalysts were carried out using a thermogravimeter (Seiko, TG/DTA 200). The weight loss was measured with increasing temperature to 800°C at 10°C/min under an air flow of 100ml/min. X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku D/MAX Ultima III) with Cu Kα X-ray radiation (λ =0.1542nm) filtered with an Ni filter under the operation conditions of 40kV and 40mA. The crystallinity of the catalysts was calculated by comparison of the characteristic peaks of uniform mesopores of the catalysts with those of pure supports. The crystallinity of the pure mesoporous materials was set to 100%. The morphology of the supports and catalysts was examined using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi, S-4700). The adsorption isotherms of nitrogen on the supports and catalysts were obtained using an automatic adsorption–desorption measuring apparatus (Mirae SI, Nanoporosity-XQ). The samples were evacuated at 200°C for 3h and then exposed to nitrogen at the temperature of liquid nitrogen. The surface area was calculated from nitrogen adsorption isotherms using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation, and the pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The IR spectra of materials incorporated in the silica supports were recorded on an FT-IR spectrophotometer (BIO-RAD 175C) equipped with an in situ cell (Graseby Specac). A ∼10mg sample wafer was installed in the sample holder and then activated at 100°C for 1h under a nitrogen flow of 50ml/min. IR spectra were obtained in the range of 4000–700cm−1 with a resolution of 4cm−1. To measure the IR spectra of the liquid samples, KBr wafers coated with liquid thin films were employed. The elementary analysis result of mXD-GP adduct was obtained using an automatic elemental analyzer (Thermo Fisher, Flash 2000). 2.4 Knoevenagel condensation The Knoevenagel condensation between BA (99%, Aldrich) and ECA (98%, Aldrich) was carried out in a two-neck round-bottomed flask. 0.25g of solid catalyst was added to a solution of BA (50mmol) and ECA (50mmol) dissolved in toluene (500mmol). The condensation proceeded at 70°C with stirring at 250rpm under a nitrogen flow of 30ml/min to eliminate oxygen and carbon dioxide. For the condensation over the homogeneous mXD and pXD base catalysts, the catalyst loading was 0.3mmol. Reactants with different pK a such as ethyl acetoacetate (EAA, 99%, Aldrich) and diethyl malonate (DEM, 99%, Aldrich) were used to compare their reactivity with ECA. Benzylamine (BZ, 98%, Aldrich) and diethylenetriamine (DETA, 99%, Aldrich) with different basicities were used to clarify the effect of catalyst basicity on the condensation. A small amount of HCl solution was added to examine the poisoning of the base by acid in the condensation. In the repeated use, the catalyst recovered by a centrifuge was added to another reactant without further treatment. For the fourth use, the catalyst was treated by DETA to remove acidic contaminants followed by washing with a sufficient amount of methanol. The product was analyzed with a gas chromatograph (Donam DS6200) equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (0.25μm×0.32mm×30m) and a flame ionization detector. The conversion of the condensation was defined by the percentage of BA consumed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The amounts of GP and XD incorporated in silica are important for determining their incorporated states, because XD is incorporated only in GP, not directly in silica. Scheme 1 shows the incorporation steps of GP and mXD in silica. Although the amount of mXD cannot exceed that of GP, two different states of mXD incorporation are possible according to the ratio of the incorporated amount of mXD to that of GP (the ratio of GP:mXD). If the ratio of GP:mXD is 1:1, one primary amine group of mXD is converted into a secondary amine group, while the other remains as a primary amine group without reacting with mXD. When the ratio of GP:mXD is 2:1, all the amine groups of mXD become secondary amine groups, because an amine group reacts with each GP. If the amount of GP incorporated in a silica support is much less than that of the hydroxyl groups of the support, and the ratio of GP to mXD is 1:1, most of the mXD is sparsely dispersed on the support in state A, possessing one secondary amine and one intact primary amine. When the amount of GP is high and the ratio of GP to mXD is between 1:1 and 2:1, the mXD molecules can be incorporated in states A and B. If the amount of GP incorporated approaches its maximum and the ratio of GP to mXD is 2:1, all the mXD molecules are incorporated in state B with the formation of two secondary amine groups per mXD molecule. Fig. 1(A) shows the TG curves of GP(x)-SBA with different amounts of GP incorporated in SBA. SBA without any mXD incorporated exhibited only one weight loss below 100°C due to the desorption of weakly adsorbed water. The incorporation of GP reduced the weight loss that occurred below 100°C, but generated a new weight loss at around 300°C. The decrease of the surface hydroxyl groups on the surface of SBA by the incorporation of GP caused the reduction of the first weight loss, but the combustion of GP incorporated at elevated temperatures caused a second weight loss. The exothermic peaks at around 300°C observed in differential thermal analysis (DTA) curves confirmed this. The maximum amount of GP incorporated was 0.73mmol/g, even though the amounts of GP added increased to 4.0mmol/g. Since the cross-sectional area of GP calculated using ChemDraw was 7.4×10−20 m2, the surface area of SBA occupied by GP was 32m2/g, indicating that the surface area of SBA, 708m2/g, was sufficiently large for such an amount of GP incorporation. The subsequent incorporation of mXD in GP(0.73)-SBA caused appreciable changes in TG/DTA curves, as shown in Fig. 1(B). The combustion of GP and mXD incorporated in mXD-GP-SBA occurred in the range of 280–600°C according to their chemical state, resulting in gradual weight losses in TG curves. Since the maximum amount of mXD incorporated in GP(0.73)-SBA was 0.38mmol/g, the ratio of GP to mXD incorporated in mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA was 2:1. Two molecules of GP held one molecule of mXD, forming the B state shown in Scheme 1, while the incorporation of each mXD molecule in each GP molecule forming the A state at the maximum incorporation was impossible. SEM photos of SBA, GP(0.73)-SBA, mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA, and pXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA are shown in Fig. S1 (see Supplementary Information). The SBA comprised bent rod-like particles. The incorporation of GP and mXD or pXD in SBA did not induce any changes on the external surface due to the formation of lumps. If the GP and mXD incorporated in SBA are located in its mesopores, their incorporation should induce significant pore filling. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of SBA, GP(x)-SBA, and mXD(y)-GP(x)-SBA. The characteristic peaks of SBA at 2 theta=0.8° indicated the presence of well-ordered mesopores [15–17]. However, the incorporation of GP gradually reduced the intensity of the peak by pore filling. The reduction of peak intensity without any accompanying shift of the 2 theta value suggested the random filling of pores by GP, without forming a uniform layer of GP. The subsequent incorporation of mXD in GP(0.73)-SBA greatly decreased the diffraction peaks at 2 theta=0.8°. No appreciable diffraction peaks were observed with mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA, reflecting the disappearance of uniform mesopores by the random filing of mesopores by GP and mXD. The pore filling of SBA by the incorporation of GP and mXD was also confirmed by the change in the nitrogen adsorption isotherms, as shown in Fig. 3 . The hysteresis observed on SBA indicated the presence of uniform mesopores, but the incorporation of GP and mXD gradually decreased the width of hysteresis. The lack of definite hysteresis with mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA corresponded to the disappearance of the uniform mesopores by the incorporation of GP and mXD. The pore size distribution of mXD(y)-GP(x)-SBA shown in Fig. 4 clearly demonstrated the pore filling by the incorporation. The incorporation of GP caused partial reduction of mesopores with uniform shape and size, but most of the uniform mesopores disappeared as a result of the subsequent incorporation of mXD. The mesopores of MCM were completely filled by the incorporation of GP, so the further incorporation of mXD in GP in mesopores was impossible. The GP incorporated in SiO2 mainly reduced the pores to diameters in the range of 6–9nm. The amount of mXD incorporated in GP(1.00)-SiO2 was small, though many mesopores still remained. Table 1 lists the amounts of GP and mXD incorporated, as well as the crystallinity and the porous characteristics of the prepared supports and catalysts. The amounts of mXD incorporated in GP(1.67)-MCM and GP(1.00)-SiO2 were smaller than that in GP(0.74)-SBA. The small amount of mXD incorporated in GP(1.67)-MCM might be due to the blocking of small mesopores (d =2.8nm) by GP. The GP incorporated in the mesopores of MCM hindered the further incorporation of mXD. However, GP(1.00)-SiO2 still had many large pores of d =2–10nm. The small amount of mXD incorporated in GP(1.00)-SiO2 might be due to the heterogeneities of pore shape and size. In contrast, SBA had large mesopores that were sufficient for the further incorporation of mXD in GP. The decreases in the volume of micropores and mesopores by the incorporation of GP and mXD reflected their presence in pores. Fig. 5 shows IR spectra of the SBA, GP, GP(0.73)-SBA, mXD, mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA, and pXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA in the range of 4000–2500cm−1. A sharp band at 3740cm−1 and a broad band at 3700–3100cm−1 were observed on SBA. The former was attributed to the isolated hydroxyl bond, and the latter to various kinds of hydroxyl bonds such as twin, triple, and vicinal bonds [18,19]. GP exhibited several absorption bands in the range of 3100–2840cm−1. The CH2 and CH bands of the epoxy group appeared at 3060 and 3010cm−1, the symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching bands of the methylene groups appeared at 2940 and 2880cm−1, and the band of the methoxy groups appeared at 2840cm−1 [20]. The appearance of epoxy, methylene, and methoxy groups on GP(0.73)-SBA confirmed the incorporation of GP in SBA. The great decreases of the bands at 3740cm−1 and 2840cm−1 by the incorporation verified that GP were incorporated in SBA. The increase of the band at 3700–3100cm−1 was due to the formation of hydroxyl groups on GP in the hydrolysis. This meant that all of the methoxy groups did not react with surface hydroxyl groups, and a part of the hydroxyl groups formed in the hydrolysis remained without participating in the incorporation. mXD showed several bands at 3360, 3300, 3060, 3030, 2930, and 2860cm−1. The bands at 3360 and 3300cm−1 were attributed to a primary amine group, while the left four bands were related to the CH bonds of the benzene ring and methylene bonds [20,21]. The considerable decreases of the bands at 3360 and 3300cm−1 reflected the conversion of primary amines into secondary amines in the incorporation of mXD in GP(0.73)-SBA. The similar spectrum of pXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA to that of mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA confirmed that pXD was also incorporated in SBA in the same method of mXD. The states of GP and mXD incorporated in the mesopores of SBA can be inferred from these characterization results, whether they were incorporated with the formation of homogeneous layers, as shown in Fig. 6(A), or with heterogeneous dispersion, as shown in Fig. 6(B). The incorporation of GP and mXD was clearly confirmed by TG/DTA, N2 adsorption, and IR. If the X-ray diffraction peak at 2 theta=0.8° on SBA, GP(0.73)-SBA, and mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA was reduced step-wise by the incorporation of GP and mXD accompanying the shift of the peak to a higher angle, GP and mXD may be incorporated with the formation of homogeneous layers of GP and mXD. However, the reduction of the peak without accompanying the shift to a higher angle upon the incorporation of GP and mXD indicated the random filling of GP and mXD in the mesopores of SBA. It was certain that both GP and mXD were present in the mesopores of SBA, but their incorporated states were not uniform. 3.2 Catalyst performance in Knoevenagel condensation Since mXD has a medium basicity with pK b =4.3, mXD can catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation between BA and ECA. Fig. 7 shows the variations of the conversion with reaction time, temperature, and the amount of mXD added. The conversion rapidly increased at the beginning, but approached equilibrium conversion after 1h, at 70°C. The increase in temperature gradually increased the conversion at up to 75°C. The linear relationship between the conversion and the amount of mXD added at 70°C clearly illustrated that the condensation was catalyzed by mXD. The turnover frequency (TOF) of mXD in the Knoevenagel condensation could be calculated from the linear slope, and TOF at 70°C was 0.0072s−1. In order to affirm the importance of basicity in the condensation, the effects of pK a of the reactants, pK b of the bases, and the poisoning by acid on the conversion of the Knoevenagel condensation are shown in Fig. S2 (see Supplementary Information). The TOF on mXD decreased with increasing pK a value of the reactants. Since the high pK a of a reactant means that it has low acidity, mXD cannot activate the reactant, and the conversion should be low. The conversion in the condensation of BA and EAA (pK a =11.0) was reduced to 11%, and that in the condensation of BA and DEM (pK a =13.0) was reduced to 3%. A strong base with lower pK b value than mXD enhanced the conversion with the same reactant. The conversion on DETA with pK b =3.8 was high at 81%, while that on BZ with pK b =4.7 was low at 14%. The addition of HCl solution reduced the conversion, confirming the contribution of base catalysts to the condensation. The dependence of the conversion upon the pK a of reactants, pK b of base catalysts, and the poisoning by acid demonstrated that the Knoevenagel condensation was catalyzed by bases. The variations of the conversion with reaction time, temperature, and the amount of catalysts added in the Knoevenagel condensation between BA and ECA over mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA are shown in Fig. 8 . The conversion increased with the reaction time and temperature. The linear increase of the conversion with the amount of catalysts added in the range of 0–0.35g confirmed that the surface reaction over the mXD catalyst determined the rate of the condensation. Furthermore, the TOF of mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA obtained from the slope was 0.0258s−1, which is about three times higher than that of liquid-state mXD. There is usually a reduction of the activity of organic bases after their incorporation into solid supports due to the change in their chemical properties and steric hindrance. However, the catalytic activity of mXD enhanced its incorporation in SBA by up to about three times. The TOF values of various XD catalysts incorporated in the silica supports are listed in Table 2 . The conversions of mXD catalysts were higher than those of pXD catalysts because of the linear configuration of pXD inducing steric hindrance. The incorporation of mXD and pXD in GP-silica supports increased their catalytic activity, regardless of the catalyst support. The mXD catalysts incorporated in SBA exhibited the highest conversion among those incorporated in MCM and SiO2 because of the large and uniform pores of SBA. The mXD-GP adduct not incorporated into any support also showed a high TOF value 0.0189s−1 compared to liquid-state mXD. The elementary analysis of the adduct stated that mXD-GP comprised 60% B state and 40% A state. The high TOF of mXD-GP was due to the formation of secondary amine groups through the reaction with GP. Furthermore, the incorporated mXD catalysts such as mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA showed similar conversion in repeated uses. The conversion in the first run was 57%, but that in the fourth was 49%. Since the negligible improvement of the conversion by washing of the catalysts used four times with DETA suggested that the decrease of the conversion was due to a slight loss of the catalyst upon filtration, not by the deactivation. 4 Conclusions mXD and pXD were successfully incorporated in GP-incorporated silica supports, but the SBA support with large mesopores (∼6.8nm) was the most suitable for the incorporation of GP and XD compared to MCM and amorphous silica. At the maximum incorporation, each mXD molecule was combined with two GP molecules, converting its primary amine groups into secondary amine groups. The mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA catalyst with the highest TOF of 0.0258s−1 showed improved catalytic activity by the incorporation compared to the TOF value of 0.0072s−1 of liquid-state mXD. The improvement in catalytic activity of XD was explained by the conversion of primary amines to secondary amines in the incorporation, and the incorporated XD catalysts were stable and maintained their catalytic activity in repeated uses. Acknowledgement This work was supported by the Priority Research Centers program (2009-0094055) through the National Research Foundation of Korea, funded by the Ministry of Education, Science, and Technology. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2013.09.033. coredata.dc:description: Meta- and para-xylylenediamine (mXD and pXD, totally XD) were incorporated on SBA-15, MCM-41, and amorphous silica supports using 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxy silane (GP) as a connecting material. The amounts and states of GP and XD incorporated in silica supports were examined by thermogravimetry, X-ray diffraction, N2 adsorption, SEM, and FT-IR. The catalytic activities of XD catalysts incorporated on the supports were investigated in the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and ethyl cyanoacetate. The maximum amount of GP incorporated in SBA-15 was 0.73mmol/g, and that of mXD was 0.38mmol/g on GP(0.73)-SBA, indicating that one mXD molecule was combined with two GP molecules. The incorporation of mXD on the silica supports through GP enhanced the catalytic activity of mXD in the condensation from TOF=0.0072s−1 on liquid-state mXD to 0.0258s−1 on mXD(0.38)-GP(0.73)-SBA. The improvement of the catalytic activities of XD by the incorporation was explained by the increase of the basicity according to the conversion of primary amine to secondary amine. The effects of the size and shape of pores on the catalytic performance of the XD catalysts incorporated in the silica supports in the condensation are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Activity improvement of xylylenediamine as a base catalyst by incorporation in SBA-15 mesoporous material
